annotation.TEXT: Hervé Villechaize became famous for delivering the line “De plane! De plane!” on the TV show Fantasy Island.
“I Spy” is a children’s guessing game that begins with one person saying “I spy, with my little eye, something …” followed by a letter, color, or other clue. The others have to then guess.
A paraphrase of a line from Prince’s 1984 song “When Doves Cry.”
The USS Arizona was a U.S. Navy battleship that was sunk in the attack on Pearl Harbor, killing 1,177 crewmen.
For most of its history, the logo of the Paramount Pictures movie studio has been some form of mountain, sometimes stylized and sometimes more realistic.
In 1986 about 6.5 million people joined hands from New York City to Long Beach, CA, raising $34 million for charity in an event known as Hands Across America.
Carl Sagan was an astronomer and author.
Rip Torn is an actor best known for playing producer Artie on The Larry Sanders Show.
Comedian Bob Hope appeared in many TV specials from 1950-96; actors Brooke Shields (1981) and Erik Estrada (1979) were both guests on various shows.
A line from the 1986 Tom Cruise jet fighter film Top Gun. “Speed” is also a slang term for amphetamines, which were once used as antidepressants.
In Domino’s ads in the ‘80s, the Noid wore a red suit with rabbit-like ears and tried to foil their delivery guarantee, among other schemes.
The TV show The Untouchables had two characters named Rico and Youngfellow, but an SNL parody called them Rico and Youngblood; the Frank Zappa song “The Untouchables” repeated the error.
The Weather Channel is a cable network launched in 1982 as a 24-hour weather service featuring local forecasts and weather news.
The “Geneva Convention” are four major treaties regarding the treatment of prisoners, civilians, and casualties during wartime.
He was voiced by Billy Costello for two years and then by Jack Mercer until his death in 1984.
King of rock & roll Elvis Presley was being prescribed a plethora of pills at the end of his life. He overdosed several times and finally died from a drug-induced heart attack.
Dr. Frasier Crane said “Tell me, what color is the sky in your world?” to postman Cliff Clavin on the popular ‘80s sitcom Cheers.
In filmmaking, matte paintings are special effect backgrounds. They used to be painted on glass and placed in front of the camera; now they are mostly made on computers.
Mr. Haney was a rural salesman and con artist on the sitcom Green Acres. He was played by Pat Buttram.
Cary Grant played leading roles in classic films, such as Bringing Up Baby and North by Northwest.
“Mine eyes have seen the glory” is a line from “The Battle Hymn of the Republic,” written by Julia Ward Howe in 1861.
“Young Love” is a 1956 song by Ric Cartey that became more popular thanks to 1957 remakes by Sonny James, Tab Hunter, and The Crew-Cuts.
Weight Watchers is a company that has provided meals and weight-loss support since 1963.
Probably a reference to those little clips on kids’ coats to keep their mittens attached so they can’t lose them.
Major Kong was Slim Pickens’s character in the film Dr. Strangelove. Kong famously rides a nuclear bomb down to its target in the USSR.
A riff on a line in the movie Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.
Kingsford is a brand of charcoal. “Edges light quickly” and “burn clean” are references to an old Kingsford ad slogan.
Bugs Bunny is the trickster rabbit from the Warner Bros. shorts.
This is a southern colloquialism meaning that the person has buck teeth.
Popeye the Sailor Man is a character created by E. C. Segar in 1929 for the Thimble Theatre comic strip.
Probably a reference to the book Nonsense Songs and Stories by Edward Lear, the Victorian children’s poet of “Owl and the Pussycat” fame.
Forrest Tucker played Sgt. Morgan O’Rourke on the ‘60s sitcom F Troop.
Without further ado, we present…the fully-annotated Crawling Eye!
This phrase originated with title cards used in silent films; in westerns, it was often “Meanwhile, back at the ranch ...”
Fannie Flagg is an best known for her novel Fried Green Tomatoes at the Whistle Stop Cafe.
A paraphrasing of the title song from the Rodgers & Hammerstein musical The Sound of Music.
The Crawling Eye: Fully annotated by The Official MST3K YouTube Channel.
Starsky & Hutch was a TV series about two tough cops who fought crime on the streets of Southern California.
Sagan also hosted the popular PBS science show Cosmos.
Another Dustin Hoffman line from Rain Man.
In the early ‘80s, the ad campaign for Certs breath mints focused on people meeting each other thanks to covering up their foul breath with Certs.
Svengali is a character in the 1894 novel Trilby, by George du Maurier; it created the archetype for the “evil hypnotist” character.
With annotations provided by The Annotated MST website.
Snuggle brand fabric softener has as its mascot a teddy bear known as Snuggle the Fabric Softener Bear. It has been voiced in ads by former Monkee Micky Dolenz.
“Tora! Tora! Tora!” was the code phrase used by Japanese pilots as they prepared to attack Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941.
This is the famous theme to the spaghetti western The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, written by composer Ennio Morricone.
Burl Ives was an actor, writer, and singer famous for voicing Sam the Snowman in the TV special Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer.
Brought to you by the Official MST3K YouTube Channel.
An imitation of Señor Wences, a Spanish ventriloquist known for his comic banter with a head in a box who went by the name of Pedro.
Nintendo is a gaming company that has produced multiple highly successful game systems, including the NES, the Game Boy, and the Wii.
Beginning in 1933, Popeye became an animated character, thanks to Fleischer Studios.
In the film Rain Man, a box of toothpicks spills in a diner, and Dustin Hoffman’s character correctly counts the 246 that land on the floor.
In The Shining, Jack Nicholson hacks through a door with an ax and says maniacally through the hole, ”Wendy, I’m home” and, more famously, “Heeere’s Johnny!”
A running gag on the TV series Police Squad! Leslie Nielsen, who played Detective Frank Drebin, always replied, “Yes, it is,” whenever he was offered a smoke.
Cheech and Chong’s self-titled debut album had a famous track called “Dave” that featured Cheech, playing Dave, trying to get Chong to let him into his own apartment.
The Eiger Sanction is an action film directed by and starring Clint Eastwood as an art history professor/assassin who must join a mountain climbing team.
Horoscopes are listings of predictions based on the Zodiac, a collection of 12 constellations organized by birthdates. They are often printed in newspapers.
Thumper is the rabbit in Bambi.
Kleenex is a brand of facial tissue that has become an informal brand eponym for all such tissues.
Michael Nesmith was one of The Monkees, a ‘60s musical group that had their own TV show. His signature was a green wool hat with a pompom.
In the film The Ladies Man, comedian Jerry Lewis famously belted, “Hey, laaaady!”
This is the rallying cry of animated superhero Mighty Mouse, created by Terrytoons in 1942 as a parody of Superman.
Rear projection consists of showing a film behind the actors to make it look as if they’re driving.
“Shave and a Haircut” is the name of a 7-note musical phrase often used as a secret knock, with the response being “Two bits,” meaning 25 cents.
In 1980 a live-action musical comedy film starring Robin Williams as Popeye was released.
Ward Cleaver, played by Hugh Beaumont, was the all-knowing father on the TV sitcom Leave It to Beaver.
Red Dye no. 2 (not 7) is a food coloring that gives food and makeup a dark red to purple color. It was banned in the U.S. in 1976 after it was linked to cancer.
Jimmy Hoffa was president of the Teamsters from 1958-71. He was famously mobbed up, and in 1975 he vanished from a restaurant parking lot, never to be seen again.
F Troop was about a dimwitted company of US Army soldiers at the fictional outpost of Fort Courage in the 19th century.
In the ‘80s, a series of ads for L’Oréal mascara used the line, “Long, longer, longest eyelashes for batting at the boys.”
Harpo Marx, clad in a curly red wig and a trench coat, never spoke in any of the Marx Brothers movies, relying on his brilliant flair for physical comedy to generate the laughs.
“Method acting” is the term given to performers who immerse themselves in their roles rather than simply recite lines and imitate emotions.
In 1981, a film came out on Nostradamus called The Man Who Saw Tomorrow that included both of these “prophecies.” It was edited in 1991 to refocus on Saddam Hussein.
Popeye’s foil was Bluto (sometimes called Brutus), a tall, burly fellow with black hair and a bushy black beard.
We hope you enjoyed this fully-annotated presentation of The Crawling Eye
The theme song was composed by Sammy Lerner for the first Popeye cartoon and has been used ever since.
Comedian Groucho Marx was the leader of the Marx Brothers.
Daniel Boone was an American frontiersman whose exploits have become embellished and inflated (partly by Boone himself) to folk hero status.
Bozo the Clown is a beloved children’s character who was portrayed by multiple actors on local TV shows, most famously by Chicago’s Bob Bell.
That Was Then, This Is Now is a YA novel about the changing relationship between two adopted brothers; it was made into a film starring Emilio Estevez.
Bluto was voiced by William Pennell and Gus Wickie, among others.
F Troop aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967.
This is the theme song to F Troop.
In the James Bond series of films, Bond famously drinks his martinis “shaken, not stirred.”
Decades ago, movies came on multiple reels. A mark near the end let the projectionist know it was almost time for the next reel, so the change would be fairly seamless. Not like this was at all.
The character Popeye has entered the public domain outside the U.S. but is still under copyright in America.
Dick Cavett is a talk show host who had shows on six different networks.
Putting a sleeping person’s hand in a bowl of warm water supposedly makes them wet the bed.
Mr. Spock was a character on the classic sci-fi TV show Star Trek. He was played by Leonard Nimoy.
Forrest Tucker and Larry Storch played the two scheming non-commissioned officers of the troop, always looking to make a quick buck.
An imitation of “Mother” from the Alfred Hitchcock film Psycho. “Norman” is Norman Bates, proprietor of the Bates Motel.
Discover the meaning behind every reference and have your mind blown.
A paraphrasing of how famed journalist Walter Winchell used to open his radio broadcasts.
“Cielito Lindo” is a popular Mexican song, best known for the line, “Ay, ay, ay, ay.” It is frequently played by mariachi bands.
Duncan Toys Company of Ohio is best known for their line of yo-yos, including the famed Duncan Imperial.
AM radio can have greater range than FM, but FM has the capacity for greater sound quality. That’s why most music stations are on the FM side of the dial.
Did we miss a reference? Let us know in the comments!
Did we miss any references? Let us know in the comments!
Captain Parmenter was the hapless commander of F Troop; the part was played by Ken Berry.
Let us know if we missed any references!
“Nasty Nasty” is a 1977 single from British punk band 999.
In 1979, Domino’s Pizza guaranteed their pizza would arrive within 30 minutes or it was free. In 1993, after millions in lawsuits due to speeding drivers, the guarantee was dropped.
A reference to the end of The Wizard of Oz, when Dorothy wakes up back in Kansas with her family gathered around her bed.
The Eiffel Tower is a Paris landmark, designed and erected by Gustave Eiffel in 1889 for the Paris World’s Fair.
In football, “hut” is often called by quarterbacks when initiating a play.
A portion of the lyrics to Johnny Nash’s hit single “I Can See Clearly Now.”
Fluffy is a common name for small pets like rabbits, hamsters, etc.
In the classic film Citizen Kane, the elderly Charles Foster Kane (played by Orson Welles) dies while holding a snow globe and saying, “Rosebud.”
